awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Corporate Law, Finance, and Productivity in Historical Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
This research studies the legal and institutional foundations of industrial and financial development. The particulars of commercial, contract, enterprise, and corporate law can have major consequences for how firms are organized and financed, with repercussions for the pace and structure of economic development in a society. The investigators examine the case of the Russian Empire around the turn of the twentieth century, because it offers a combination of uniquely high quality data and a particular set of legal and financial characteristics, all of which make it possible to study the relationships among company law, finance, and firm performance in an industrializing economy. This project collects and analyzes the new dataset while training a large number of undergraduate research assistants in statistical and research methods. 

This project involves the collection and analysis of firm-level data describing Russian corporations before the October Revolution of 1917. The data collection is international in scope, drawing on original corporate charters, archival records of firms and financial markets, and a wealth of historical newspapers, government reports, and other materials culled from archives and libraries in the United States, Russia, and Europe. The new dataset links the legal rules governing individual corporations to their subsequent financial characteristics, productivity, and market valuations. The publicly-available databases generated as part of the project are of interest to scholars in diverse fields such as corporate law, finance, economic history, economic geography, industrial organization, and Russian history. The Imperial Russian setting not only offers data of uniquely high quality for a developing economy, but it also provides substantial variation in the legal structures of corporations and in the underlying financial and industrial conditions. This enables the econometric evaluation of causal hypotheses regarding how corporations were financed and how Imperial Russian legal and economic institutions functioned. Thus, this historical project speaks to the role that legal institutions, corporate governance, and finance play in the process of economic development. The project's findings are salient for understanding the historical context of current legal and economic conditions in the Russian Federation, an area of current U.S. policy concern. This research involves undergraduate research assistants at every stage. These students learn methods of data coding, acquire skills in estimating econometric models, become conversant with a broad and interdisciplinary scholarship, and gain experience working with Russian-language sources. Mentoring undergraduates aligns with goals of both principal investigators' primarily undergraduate institutions.

por.por_cntn:
This project entailed four central goals: collecting unique data on the financing, legal character, and outcomes (output, workers hired, profitablity, etc.) for a large sample of corporations in a historical developing economy - namely, late Imperial Russia; writing papers and a book prospectus summarizing and analyzing these data that provide insights into how firms organize and finance themselves in the early stages of industrial development; training and employing undergraduate students to help conduct this research; and disseminating our research in seminars, conferences, through online portals and a web site, and through the standard publication channels. 

Besides publishing one paper (Amanda Gregg and Steven Nafziger, “Capital Structure and Corporate Performance in Late Imperial Russia” European Review of Economic History 23.4 (2019): 446-481), we - my co-PI Amanda Gregg and I - have three other papers at different stages of the publication process (as of 11/2021):

1. "Corporate Finance of Industry in a Developing Economy: Panel Evidence from Imperial Russia"(previously circulated as "Financial Dynamics: Imperial Russian Corporate Balance Sheets, 1899 to 1914") is currently Revise and Resubmit at the Financial History Review

2. "The Births, Lives, and Deaths of Corporations in Late Imperial Russia" was issued as Bank of Finland Instiutute for Economies in Transition Discussion Paper 26 (2020) and is currently Revise and Resubmit at The Economic Journal

3. with Amy Dayton, a former undergraduate research assistant on the project, "Shareholder Democracy under Autocracy: Voting Rights and Corporate Performance in Imperial Russia," issued as European Corporate Governance Institute Finance Working Paper 773/2021.

In addition, the underlying datasets for these papers are on track to be made public by the end of 2022 via the project's web site (https://sites.google.com/williams.edu/russianhistoricalcorporations/home), and we are beginning the planning for a book that will synthesize the findings from this project and related research.

Overall, our results show the importance of both contextual factors AND underlying corporate fundamentals in determining various financial and economic outcomes for firms in this developing country setting. Imperial Russian corporations did look and act a lot like those operating in much more developed economies of the time and were comparable in their financial structures and decision-making to modern corporations. We establish these new findings using detailed statistical analyses of the new datasets we have developed, which are based on following Imperial Russian corporations over time between the 1890s and 1914. These "modern" attributes are evident despite the general weaknesses of the financial and legal systems at the time. This bears directly on how we can understand corporate activity in the early stages of industrial, financial, and economic development.

In addition, we have established several interesting new results with respect to Imperial Russian corporate governance. First, we found that Russian corporations in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries gave small shareholders considerably more power than those in other, more developed contexts. Second, we find considerable variation among governance provisions for these Russian corporations, which we can explain based on corporate sector, age, financing, and other characteristics. Third, we find that these governance structures are related to how well these corporations performed on stock markets, consistent with findings in other contexts.

Overall, our project has generated insights that will be impactful in several ways. First, our research contributes a number of hypotheses and empirical tests regarding the mechanisms underlying historical Russian corporations' governance, financing, and performance. Establishing linkages between how a firm is governed, financed, and ultimately performs is of central concern to several areas of economics, and our work with the unique context and data of Imperial Russia can provide important insights. 

Second, we are contributing a comprehensive database documenting historical Russian corporations on an annual basis from 1900 to 1914. We are currently merging materials from corporate charters, financial balance sheets, industrial censuses, tax records, and securities prices and wlll make the resulting dataset availabkle soon. These data will be of interest to scholars in economic history, economics, finance, and corporate law.

Finally, both PIs have trained and provided hands-on research experience to a significant number undergraduate reseach assistants (while gaining complementary experience in new areas of economics ourselves), which will help many of them as they pursue further graduate training in economics and related fields.

Beyond the field of economics, our project's findings are of central importance to scholars in Slavic Studies and History, who work to conceptualize the early stages of modern Russian economic development. Moreover, our research into historical corporate finance and governance provides empirical context to key ideas in finance and corporate law in a relatively under studied (and low income) region.

Finally, we believe that our project can inform regulatory and economic policy decisions regarding the law, financing, and competitive environments of industrial corporations and firms in low income countries.

Modified by: Steven E Nafziger
